title: Europe’s Energy Crisis Exposes Old Fault Lines and New Power Dynamics
description: Smaller countries see Germany’s domestic largess to tackle spiraling energy costs as undermining the effort to lower fuel prices for the wider European Union.
dc:creator: Matina Stevis-Gridneff
media:credit: Patrick Junker for The New York Times
media:description: Energy facilities at Wilhelmshaven, a German hub for liquefied natural gas imports. Critics say Germany should prioritize lowering the price of natural gas for the whole E.U., instead of maneuvering to secure more for itself.
